facts.text: This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution to quash the order of the first respondent dated April 28, 1960, and the scheme dated April 20, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by A SUBBA RAO J.-This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution to quash the order of the first respondent dated April 28, 1960, and the scheme dated April 20, 1960, and to direct the first respondent to deal with the application of the petitioner for renewal of its permit in accordance with law.

facts.text: The petitioner was doing business of motor transport in Bombay State for over 20 years.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was doing business of motor transport in Bombay State for over 20 years. It had four permanent stage carriage permits granted some years ago and renewed from time to time to ply buses on the following routes Yeotmal-Umerkhed 2 return trips.

facts.text: Petitioner had four permanent stage carriage permits for routes Yeotmal-Umerkhed 2 return trips and Yeotmal-Pusad 4 return trips.

anchor.surface_text: It had four permanent stage carriage permits granted some years ago and renewed from time to time to ply buses on the following routes Yeotmal-Umerkhed 2 return trips. Yeotmal-Pusad 4 return trips.

facts.text: The term of the latest permits expired on December 31, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The term of the latest permits expired on December 31, 1959. About four months prior to the expiry of the permits the petitioner applied on August 24, 1959, for the renewal of the permits under s. 58 2  of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939  Act IV of 1939 ,  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Petitioner applied on August 24, 1959, for the renewal of the permits under s. 58(2) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: About four months prior to the expiry of the permits the petitioner applied on August 24, 1959, for the renewal of the permits under s. 58 2  of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939  Act IV of 1939 ,  hereinafter called the Act . On October 29, 1959, the State Transport Department published its proposed scheme for the nationalization of the road transport services in respect of an area which included the routes of the petitioner.

facts.text: On October 29, 1959, the State Transport Department published its proposed scheme for nationalization including petitioner's routes.

anchor.surface_text: On October 29, 1959, the State Transport Department published its proposed scheme for the nationalization of the road transport services in respect of an area which included the routes of the petitioner.

facts.text: On November 9, 1959, the petitioner wrote a letter to the Secretary, Regional Transport Authority, Nagpur, questioning non-publication of renewal application.

anchor.surface_text: On November 9, 1959, the petitioner wrote a letter to the Secretary, the Regional Transport Authority, Nagpur, asking him why its application for renewal of the stage carriage permits had number been published as required by s. 57 of the Act.

facts.text: Secretary, Regional Transport Authority replied on November 11, 1959, that application published on November 8, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Secretary, the Regional Transport Authority, by his letter dated November 11, 1959, replied to the effect that the application for renewal had been published on November 8, 1959, and that the said application would be companysidered before the expiry date

facts.text: On November 19, 1959, Assistant Manager of State Transport Department filed applications for permits on the routes.

anchor.surface_text: On November 19, 1959, the Assistant Manager of the State Transport Department on behalf of the State Transport Department filed applications before the Regional Transport Authority for issue of permits to it in respect of the said two routes among others.

facts.text: On December 10, 1959, the applications were published in the Gazette.

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1959, the said applications were published in the Gazette and it was numberified therein that representations, if any, should be submitted on or before December 15, 1959,

facts.text: On December 21, 1959, Secretary RTA intimated petitioner that renewal applications could not be considered on December 31 due to heavy agenda.

anchor.surface_text: On December 21, 1959, the Secretary of the Regional Transport Authority intimated to the petitioner that in the meeting of the Regional Transport Authority scheduled to be held on December 31, 1959, it would number be possible to companysider its applications for renewal due to heavy agenda .

facts.text: On December 29, 1959, temporary permits issued for one month from January 1, 1960, extended to March 31, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1959, temporary permits were issued for one month from January 1, 1960, and thereafter they were extended for another month and made available upto March 31, 1960.

facts.text: Meeting on February 5, 1960 adjourned to February 24, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The ,next meeting of the Regional Transport Authority scheduled to be held on February 5, 1960, was adjourned to February 24, 1960,

facts.text: On January 22, 1960, Chief Minister issued notices that objections to scheme would be heard on February 24, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: and on January 22, 1960, the Chief Minister of Bombay issued numberices to the petitioner and others that objections to the proposed scheme would be heard on February 24, 1960

facts.text: On February 24, 1960, applications not disposed as matter sub judice in High Court of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: but on the said date the applications were number disposed of on the ground that the matter was sub judice in the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: On March 17, 1960, Provincial Transport Services filed fresh application under Ch. IVA.

anchor.surface_text: On March 17, 1960, the Provincial Transport Services filed a fresh application before the Regional Transport Authority under Ch. IVA of the Act for the grant of permits for plying buses on the routes mentioned therein.

facts.text: On March 31, 1960, RTA met but did not consider petitioner's renewal applications.

anchor.surface_text: On March 31, 1960, the Regional Transport Authority met again, but the applications for renewal of permits filed by the petitioner were number taken up for companysideration.

facts.text: On April 14, 1960, Chief Minister heard objections to the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: On April 14, 1960, the Chief Minister of Bombay heard the objections

facts.text: On April 19, 1960, scheme approved with modifications, published April 20, 1960, including petitioner's routes.

anchor.surface_text: and on April 19, 1960, the scheme with modifications was duly approved by the Government and published on April 20, 1960. The approved scheme companyered only the routes in respect of which only tem- porary permits were issued and excluded the routes in regard to which pucca permits were issued. The approved scheme included the petitioners routes.

facts.text: On April 26, 1960, petitioner moved Supreme Court under Art.32, dismissed April 28, 1960 as premature.

anchor.surface_text: On April 26, 1960, the petitioner moved this Court under Art.32 of the Constitution and on April 28, 1960, the petition was dismissed as premature.

facts.text: On April 28, 1960, RTA rejected renewal applications on ground scheme approved.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day even though the Regional Transport Authority was informed that this Court was moved by the petitioner its renewal applications were rejected on the ground that the scheme was approved by the Government.

facts.text: Present petition filed on April 29, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The present petition was filed on April 29, 1960, for the aforesaid reliefs.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on September 8, 1960 by A Subba Rao J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. September 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by A SUBBA RAO J.-This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution to quash the order of the first respondent dated April 28, 1960,

facts.text: Regional Transport Authority had power under s. 68F(2) to reject applications after scheme approved.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the Regional Transport Authority had power under s. 68F 2  of the Act in the circumstances of the case to reject the applications filed by the petitioner.

facts.text: Court finds no mala fides by Regional Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The record in this case is number indicative of promptitude or efficiency in the matter of discharge of the statutory functions by the Regional Transport Authority. ... Considering the facts and circumstances of this case, we cannot say that the companyplaint of the petitioner that the adjournments were number for the reasons mentioned in the orders but were only to give time to enable the Government to approve the scheme, may number be wholly unjustified.

facts.text: Temporary permits granted more than once, transgression of s.62 proviso.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that under the second proviso to s. 62 temporary permits companyld number have been granted more than once, but a transgression of that provision by the Regional Transport Authority does number affect the question raised.

facts.text: Scheme approved in public interest considering resources of PTS.

anchor.surface_text: The Chief Minister found on the material placed before him that it was necessary in the public interest that the scheme submitted by the Provincial Transport Services should be approved.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges discrimination in scheme excluding its route but allowing others.

anchor.surface_text: The next companytention of the learned companynsel is that the scheme suffers from the vice of discrimination inasmuch as, though it excluded the petitioner from operating on the route between Yeotmal and Umerkhed, it allowed others to ply their buses on that route

facts.text: No basis for discrimination plea in affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberbasis for this argument in the affidavit filed by the petitioner is support of the writ petition. We do number think that we are justified in allowing the petitioner to raise the plea for the first time before us.

facts.text: Chief Minister confirmed scheme on merits considering PTS resources and amenities.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 24 of his order the Chief Minister observed, On merits, it is quite clear to me that having regard to the resources of the P. T. S. and the amenities that it provides to the public, it is in the public interest that the scheme submitted by the P. T. S., Nagpur, should be approved .

issues.text: whether the Regional Transport Authority was actuated by mala fides in the disposal of the applications for renewal of the permits, and that though under the provisions of the Act it had no alternative but to renew the permits of the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: The present petition was filed on April 29, 1960, for the aforesaid reliefs. The main contention of learned counsel, Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, for the petitioner, is that the Regional Transport Authority was actuated by mala fides in the disposal of the applications for renewal of the permits, and that

issues.text: whether the Regional Transport Authority acted without jurisdiction in rejecting the applications some months after the date of the expiry of the terms of the permits

anchor.surface_text: As the provisions of the Act do not prescribe any time limit for the disposal of an application for renewal of permits, we cannot hold that the Regional Transport Authority acted without jurisdiction in rejecting the applications some months after the date of the expiry of the terms of the permits. issues.text: whether the Regional Transport Authority exceeded its power in rejecting the applications

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the Regional Transport Authority exceeded its power in rejecting the applications. In this context it will be convenient to read the relevant portions of s. 68F, which read Section 68F (1) Where, in pursuance of an approved scheme, any State transport undertaking applies

holdings.text: The provisions of the Act do not prescribe any time limit for the disposal of an application for renewal of permits; therefore, the Regional Transport Authority did not act without jurisdiction in rejecting the applications some months after the expiry of the permits.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that under the second proviso to s. 62 temporary permits could not have been granted more than once, but a transgression of that provision by the Regional Transport Authority does not affect the question raised. As the provisions of the Act do not prescribe any time limit for the disposal of an applic

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act lacks explicit time limit for renewal disposal; temporary permit issues irrelevant; mandamus available for delay but not sought.

holdings.text: A transgression of the second proviso to s.62 by granting temporary permits more than once does not affect the validity of rejecting the renewal applications.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1959, temporary permits were granted for one month and after the expiry of those permits, another set of temporary permits was issued for another month ending with March 31, 1960. It is true that under the second proviso to s. 62 temporary permits could not have been granted more

holdings.reasoning_summary: Irrelevant to jurisdiction or power to reject under s.68F.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority had power under s.68F(2) to refuse to entertain (reject as not maintainable) the petitioner's renewal applications to give effect to the approved scheme, even though applications were filed before scheme approval.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the legislature used the word entertain to bring about that result. A wider meaning of the word entertain would enable the smooth working of the provisions of the section and we have no reason to accept the narrower meaning suggested by the learned counsel. We, therefore, hol

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.68F(2) not conditioned by s.68F(1); 'entertain' means reject without merits consideration post-scheme approval; purposive interpretation avoids anomaly of granting then cancelling permits.

holdings.text: The petitioner is not permitted to raise the plea of discrimination in the scheme for the first time before the Supreme Court, as there is no basis for it in the supporting affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention of the learned counsel is that the scheme suffers from the vice of discrimination inasmuch as, though it excluded the petitioner from operating on the route between Yeotmal and Umerkhed, it allowed others to ply their buses on that route on their way from Akola to Umerkhed or

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea not raised in affidavit; Supreme Court will not allow new pleas without basis.

holdings.text: The Chief Minister did not confirm the scheme on extraneous considerations; consideration of PTS resources and amenities is relevant under s.68C for public interest.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it is argued that the Chief Minister confirmed the scheme on extraneous considerations not covered by s. 68C of the Act. holdings.reasoning_summary: Factors like resources and amenities go to efficient service in public interest as per s.68C.

holdings.text: The Regional Transport Authority was not actuated by mala fides warranting quashing of its order rejecting the renewal applications.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the legislature used the word entertain to bring about that result. A wider meaning of the word entertain would enable the smooth working of the provisions of the section and we have no reason to accept the narrower meaning suggested by the learned counsel. We, therefore, hol

holdings.reasoning_summary: Delays suspicious but no proof; valid power under s.68F(2) exercised.

holdings.text: A statutory tribunal is expected to discharge its functions fairly and without bias even where government interests are involved.

anchor.surface_text: The record in this case is not indicative of promptitude or efficiency in the matter of discharge of the statutory functions by the Regional Transport Authority. holdings.reasoning_summary: General observation on natural justice despite no finding of bias here.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the Regional Transport Authority had power under s. 68F 2 of the Act in the circumstances of the case to reject the applications filed by the petitioner.

outcome.relief_summary: Court upheld the Regional Transport Authority's power under s.68F(2) to reject petitioner's renewal applications after scheme approval; rejected other contentions including discrimination and extraneous considerations
